natural problem: Let $x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n$ be real numbers which satisfy $|x_i| < 1$ for $i = 1, 2, \dots, n,$ and \[|x_1| + |x_2| + \dots + |x_n| = 19 + |x_1 + x_2 + \dots + x_n|.\]What is the smallest possible value of $n$?
natural solution: The left-hand side satisfies \[|x_1| + |x_2| + \dots + |x_n| < 1 + 1 + \dots + 1 = n,\]while the right-hand side satisfies \[19 + |x_1 + x_2 + \dots + x_n| \ge 19.\]Therefore, $n > 19,$ so $n \ge 20.$ It is possible that $n=20,$ since, for example, we can choose \[\begin{aligned} x_1 = x_2 = \dots = x_{10} &= \tfrac{19}{20}, \\ x_{11} =x_{12} = \dots =x_{20}& = -\tfrac{19}{20}, \end{aligned}\]which makes $|x_1| + |x_2| + \dots = |x_{20}| = 19$ and $|x_1 + x_2 + \dots + x_{20}| = 0.$ Therefore the answer is $\boxed{20}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. i \<le> n \<longrightarrow> abs (x i) < 1"
and h1 : "sum (\<lambda>i. abs (x i)) {..n} = 19 + abs (sum x {..n})"
shows  "n \<ge> 20"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n$ be real numbers which satisfy $|x_i| < 1$ for $i = 1, 2, \dots, n,$ and \[|x_1| + |x_2| + \dots + |x_n| = 19 + |x_1 + x_2 + \dots + x_n|.\]What is the smallest possible value of $n$? The final Answer is 20
 ### Proof
 The left-hand side satisfies \[|x_1| + |x_2| + \dots + |x_n| < 1 + 1 + \dots + 1 = n,\]while the right-hand side satisfies \[19 + |x_1 + x_2 + \dots + x_n| \ge 19.\]Therefore, $n > 19,$ so $n \ge 20.$ It is possible that $n=20,$ since, for example, we can choose \[\begin{aligned} x_1 = x_2 = \dots = x_{10} &= \tfrac{19}{20}, \\ x_{11} =x_{12} = \dots =x_{20}& = -\tfrac{19}{20}, \end{aligned}\]which makes $|x_1| + |x_2| + \dots = |x_{20}| = 19$ and $|x_1 + x_2 + \dots + x_{20}| = 0.$ Therefore the answer is $\boxed{20}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. i \<le> n \<longrightarrow> abs (x i) < 1"
and h1 : "sum (\<lambda>i. abs (x i)) {..n} = 19 + abs (sum x {..n})"
shows  "n \<ge> 20"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given a sequence of natural numbers $x$ with the property that the absolute value of each term is less than $1$ (i.e., $|x_i| < 1$ for all $i \leq n$), if the sum of the absolute values of the terms up to $n$ is equal to $19$ plus the absolute value of the sum of the terms up to $n$ (i.e., $\sum_{i=0}^{n} |x_i| = 19 + |\sum_{i=0}^{n} x_i|$), then $n$ must be greater than or equal to $20$.

theorem 
fixes x :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. i \<in> {1..n} \<longrightarrow> abs (x i) < 1"
and h1 : "sum (\<lambda>i. abs (x i)) {1..n} = 19 + abs (sum x {1..n})"
shows  "n \<ge> 20"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Let $x$ be a function that assigns a real number to each natural number. If for every number $i$ in the set from 1 to $n$, the absolute value of $x(i)$ is less than 1, and if the sum of the absolute values of $x(i)$ from 1 to $n$ equals 19 plus the absolute value of the sum of $x(i)$ from 1 to $n$, then $n$ must be at least 20.

 *)

theorem
